Explanation: The doctor suggested a 'General Examination' which aligns with the concept of 'General inspection' as both aim to assess overall appearance and visible signs of jaundice.
The doctor did not suggest any physical examination step that is similar to 'Vital signs assessment' or has a justification related to confirming recorded vitals.
The doctor did not suggest a 'Skin examination' or provide a justification related to evaluating jaundice or skin conditions.
The doctor suggested an 'Examination of Head and Neck' to assess for signs of jaundice, which includes checking for scleral icterus, thus aligning with the similar step of 'Scleral examination'.
The doctor suggested an 'Examination of Abdomen' which aligns with the similar physical examination step of 'Abdominal examination' and shares the justification of assessing for organomegaly.
The doctor did not suggest 'Palpation of the liver' or a similar examination step focused specifically on liver enlargement or tenderness.
The doctor did not suggest palpation of the spleen or any similar examination step specifically aimed at assessing splenomegaly.
The doctor did not suggest an examination of the hands and nails, which is specifically aimed at identifying signs of liver disease.
The doctor did not suggest a neurological examination or any similar step related to assessing neurological signs associated with liver dysfunction.
The doctor did not suggest an examination of the eyes or provide a justification related to checking for signs of anemia or other abnormalities.
